Therefore, alternative electrochemical energy storage systems to lithium-ion batteries are attracting great attention.[1] Among the existing prototypes, lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries are considered as one of the most promising candidates for next-generation rechargeable batteries.[2] Sulfur is a naturally abundant, cost effective, and environmentfriendly cathode material with a high theoretical specific capacity of 1675 mAh g−1. By pairing a sulfur cathode with a Li metal anode (theoretical capacity of 3860 mAh g−1), the theoretical energy density of Li–S batteries is expected to reach 2600 Wh kg−1, far superior to that of lithium-ion batteries (≈420 Wh kg−1).[2] Despite these advantages, the practical application of Li–S batteries still faces many challenges.
As shown in Figure 1a, a typical Li–S battery is built on the reversible redox reac-
tion between sulfur and its discharged product (Li2S).[2,3] When the battery is discharged, solid S8 is first reduced into a series of polysulfide intermediates (Li2Sx, 4 ≤ x ≤ 8), then further converted to Li2S2/Li2S. This two-stage process can be simplified as a reaction sequence of S8 → Li2S8–4 → Li2S2/Li2S, which corresponds to the two voltage plateaus in a discharge curve. During the charging process, Li2S is reversibly oxidized into S8 by the reverse reaction. This complicated reaction pathway, together with the inherent insulating nature of sulfur, gives rise to several obstacles for the application of Li–S batteries.[4–6] First, the insulating nature of sulfur reduces the electrochemical utilization of active materials, resulting in the low discharge capacities of Li–S batteries. Second, the polysulfides are highly soluble in the organic electrolyte used in Li–S batteries. The dissolved polysulfides can diffuse through a porous separator and form short-chain polysulfides or a passive layer on the surface of Li metal anode. The short-chain polysulfides can diffuse back to the cathode when they become concentrated and react with the long-chain polysulfides or sulfur. This repeated migration of polysulfides (the well-known “shuttling effect”) leads to the continuous loss of cathode-active materials and degradation of Li metal anode, which is also the prime culprit for the low Coulombic efficiency, poor cycling stability, and self-discharge of Li–S batteries (Figure 1b).[7] Third, the large volumetric variation (≈80%) between sulfur and Li2S during the lithiation/ delithiation process reduces the mechanical integrality and stability of sulfur cathode. Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries are considered as one of the most potential next-generation rechargeable batteries due to their high theoretical energy density. However, some critical issues, such as low capacity, poor cycling stability, and safety concerns, must be solved before Li–S batteries can be used practically. During the past decade, tremendous efforts have been devoted to the design and synthesis of electrode materials. Benefiting from their tunable structural parameters, hollow porous carbon materials (HPCM) remarkably enhance the performances of both sulfur cathodes and lithium anodes, promoting the development of high-performance Li–S batteries. Here, together with the templated synthesis of HPCM, recent progresses of Li–S batteries based on HPCM are reviewed. Several important issues in Li–S batteries, including sulfur loading, polysulfide entrapping, and Li metal protection, are discussed, followed by a summary on recent research on HPCM-based sulfur cathodes, modified separators, and lithium anodes. After the discussion on emerging technical obstacles toward high-energy Li–S batteries, prospects for the future directions of HPCM research in the field of Li–S batteries are also proposed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since Sony launched the first commercial product in 1991, rechargeable lithium-ion batteries have been constantly changing our lifestyle. From portable electronics to electric vehicles, lithium-ion batteries play an important role in supporting the development of these technologies. Yet after nearly three decades of development, the energy densities of the commercially available lithium-ion batteries based on ion-insertion material cathodes and graphite anodes are nearing their ceiling values,

During the charge/discharge process, the side reactions between Li metal anode and liquid electrolyte (i.e., the electrolyte decomposition at the anode side) not only increase the consumption of electrolyte and lithium, but also generate the gaseous products during the cycling process.[8] With a better understanding of Li–S chemistry, some strategies, including designing the sulfur-hosting materials,[9] tuning the electrolyte’s properties,[10,11] introducing a polysulfide barrier layer,[12] and regulating the Li nucleation/growth behaviors,[13] have been proposed and assessed in recent years. These effective strategies have fueled an explosive development of Li–S battery research, and considerable improvements of the capacities and cycling stabilities of Li–S batteries have been made.[14]
In the past decade, carbon as a sulfur-hosting material has played a pivotal role in the development of Li–S batteries.[15] A classic example can be dated back to 2009 when Nazar and co-workers developed a high-capacity sulfur cathode by impregnating molten sulfur into the ordered mesoporous carbon
material CMK-3.[16] This work is widely considered as one of the most significant breakthroughs in Li–S battery research. Since then, various carbon materials have been developed as the sulfur-hosting materials to increase the electrical conductivities of sulfur and reduce “shuttling effect” by improving the affinity between carbon and polysulfides. Among the carbon materials, hollow porous carbon materials (HPCM) are particularly noticeable for their high specific surface areas (SSA), available cavities, tunable pore structures, and controllable morphologies and components.[17,18] Much effort has been dedicated to designing advanced HPCM with improved sulfur loading and sulfur utilization. From physical confinement to chemical adsorption and assembly structure, the rational design of HPCM has been leading to the development of numerous sulfur cathodes.[18] HPCM has also been successfully applied in separator modification to reduce the migration of polysulfides.[19] More importantly, recent researches indicate that HPCM has considerable potential to improve the performance of Li-metal anodes.[13] Therefore, the design and synthesis of high-performance HPCM toward Li–S system are valuable for promoting current Li–S battery research.

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis of Hollow Porous Carbon Materials
sections.text:
During the last two decades, hollow porous nanostructures have emerged as an important class of carbon materials. Given its great potentials in many important fields (e.g., energy, catalysis, and nanomedicine), controllable synthesis of HPCM has been extensively investigated.[20–22] For a better understanding, most of the synthetic methods for HPCM can be classified into three major types using the templating concept (Figure 2): hard-templating, soft-templating, and self-templating strategies.
The conventional hard-templating strategy involves synthesizing solid or porous materials with desirable morphologies and porous structures (i.e., so-called hard templates or sacrificial templates), then coating them with carbon precursors, subsequent carbonization of the resultant template@carbon precursor composites, and finally selective removal of the templates (Figure 2a).[20,21] Since the pivotal step in hard-templating strategy is the coating of carbon precursor, how to design strong interaction between the template surface and carbon precursor
is particularly important. Until now, hard-templating strategy is still the most popular route to fabricate HPCM, and the majority of HPCM used in Li–S batteries are derived from hardtemplating strategy. Soft-templating strategy usually employs the surfactant-stabilized micelles or microdroplets as templates (Figure 2b).[23,24] After a solution-based carbon precursor coating and subsequent carbonization, HPCM can be directly obtained without the template removal procedure, as most surfactants are thermally decomposable. Due to the difficulty in adjusting the morphology and components, the application of the softtemplating strategy in Li–S batteries relatively lags behind that of the hard-templating strategy. The self-templating technique, also known as template-free strategy, is usually performed by directly carbonizing some hollow-structured carbon precursors (Figure 2c). This strategy shows its enormous potential in largescale fabrication. Additionally, some solid synthetic materials, such as metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), can be converted into hollow porous carbonaceous particles by controlling the carbonization process, greatly enriching the family of self-templating products.[25,26] In recent years, a growing number of self-templating HPCM have been applied in Li–S batteries.
Compared with the other two approaches, the hard-templating strategy offers a tremendous advantage in the material design, as the morphologies, sizes, and pore structures of HPCM can be precisely controlled by tuning the predesigned templates.[20,21] This strategy provides researchers with more choices when selecting templates and carbon precursors. Considering the cost and operability, the commonly used templates are silica, polymers, and metal oxides, and the available carbon precursors include methane, furfural alcohol, glucose, pitch, and phenolic resin. In addition, some N-containing compounds, such as aniline, pyrrole, dopamine, and ionic liquids, are used to synthesize

In the literature, many procedures to control the pore parameters of HPCM are based on the pioneer work reported by Hyeon and co-workers in 2002.[29] In their work, the core/ shell-structured solid SiO2@mesoporous SiO2 spheres were used as the hard templates, and hollow mesoporous carbon spheres were obtained after the impregnation of carbon precursors into the mesoporous SiO2 shell followed by carbonization and removal of silica. The concept of “the inverse replicas of mesoporous templates” was then widely employed in the past decade.[30] However, the synthesis of mesoporous silica templates is usually complicated and time-consuming, increasing the cost of the target HPCM.
The situation was improved after Qiao and co-workers reported a Stöber-similar method with derived resorcinol–formaldehyde (RF) resin and carbon spheres.[31] Uniform and dispersible colloid SiO2 spheres are readily prepared via the classic sol–gel Stöber method that generates by the hydrolysis and polymerization of silicon alkoxides (e.g., tetraethylorthosilicate, TEOS) in the mixture of water/alcohol/NH4OH. Most of the hard templates reported in the literature are produced by the Stöber method.[17] Considering that the hydrolysis–polymerization reaction mechanism of RF is analogous to that of silicate sol–gel process, Qiao
and co-workers successfully synthesized monodisperse RF spheres with tunable sizes via a one-pot Stöber method by polymerizing resorcinol and formaldehyde in the mixture of water/ alcohol/NH4OH (Figure 3a). After carbonization, the as-obtained spheres were converted to uniform carbon spheres. Followup studies revealed that the Stöber method can be expanded to many other carbon precursors, such as phenolic resin analogs, polydopamine, and polybenzoxazine (PB).[32–34]
Inspired by the success of the silicate sol–gel process in the fabrication of hollow-structured materials, the Stöber system was quickly used to synthesize HPCM. Combining the synthesis processes of SiO2 spheres and RF spheres in the Stöber system, Fuertes et al. developed a one-step and one-pot method for synthesizing core–shell-structured SiO2@RF spheres and hollow porous carbon spheres (HPCS) by the reaction of TEOS, resorcinol, and formaldehyde in the mixture of water/ alcohol/NH4OH.[35] Zheng and co-workers as well as Huo and co-workers independently reported their investigations on the controllable synthesis of hollow- and yolk/shell-carbon nanostructures by coating the solid or core/shell SiO2 particles with a layer of RF/surfactant composite in the mixture of water/ alcohol/NH4OH/cationic surfactant.[36–38] In these works, the

self-assembly of positively charged cationic surfactants (e.g., cetyltrimethylammonium bromide or -chloride (CTAB or CTAC)) and negatively charged RF on the surface of the negatively charged SiO2 template is a critical step for the RF-coating process, as the cationic surfactant enhances the interaction between RF and the silica template. To further increase the porosity of HPCM, Zheng and co-workers developed a multiple coating route to synthesize a sandwich-like SiO2@RF/CTAB@ SiO2 structure.[39] Interestingly, this structure can used to produce HPCM with foam-like shells, exhibiting a high specific surface area (1286 m2 g−1) and large pore volume (2.25 cm3 g−1), far superior to those of the SiO2@RF/CTAB-derived HPCM (639 m2 g−1 and 0.56 cm3 g−1, respectively). In order to control the pore structure and size, Dai and co-workers developed a silica-assisted process based on the co-assembly of RF, CTAC, and silicate oligomers under a modified Stöber condition (Figure 3b).[40] They constructed the core/shell-structured SiO2@RF/CTAC/SiO2 spheres via a one-pot reaction of TEOS, resorcinol, and formaldehyde in the mixture of water/alcohol/ NH4OH/CTAC. By employing SiO2 in the RF/CTAC/SiO2 layer as a pore-forming component, HPCS with radially aligned mesopores (3.2–3.6 nm in pore sizes) and tunable particle sizes (180–800 nm in diameters) were obtained through controlling the amount of TEOS and the water/alcohol volume ratio.
With a better understanding of the carbon precursor chemistry, more efforts have been devoted to simplifying the Stöber conditions for the controllable synthesis of HPCM. From surfactant free to silica free, several versatile methods have been developed in the past 3 years. Lu and co-workers reported a facile route to synthesize N-doped PB nanospheres and N-doped carbon nanospheres with tunable sizes by a one-pot condensation and polymerization of resorcinol, formaldehyde, and 1,6-diaminohexane.[41] Considering that PB is positively charged and can be electrostatically adsorbed onto negatively charged SiO2, Zheng and co-workers further designed a surfactant-free Stöber system to synthesize N-doped HPCS (Figure 3c).[42] When using resorcinol/formaldehyde/ethylenediamine as the PB precursors and TEOS as the SiO2 precursor, the prefabricated SiO2 spheres were directly coated with a layer of PB/SiO2 composites in the mixture of water/alcohol. In this system, ethylenediamine also acted as a basic catalyst for the hydrolysis of TEOS. The co-assembly of the positively charged PB and the negative charged silicate oligomers on the surface of the SiO2 spheres forms the SiO2@PB/SiO2 spheres, which can be further converted into HPCS or N-doped bowl-like HPCS. Simply by controlling the dosage of TEOS, the specific surface area of N-doped HPCS is adjustable from 763 to 2161 m2 g−1. Through controlling the SiO2 precursors, Yu and co-workers developed a surfactant-free system to synthesize HPCS with adjustable pore sizes (Figure 3d).[43] They revealed that the one-pot reaction of resorcinol, formaldehyde, and the mixture of tetrapropylorthosilicate/TEOS in the Stöber conditions can directly generate SiO2@RF/SiO2 spheres without adding cationic surfactant. Compared with the previously reported TEOS-based system, the introduction of tetrapropylorthosilicate provides better control over silica core and primary SiO2 particle formation. By adjusting the ratios of TPOS/TEOS and water/alcohol, the pore sizes of HPCS can be attuned from micropores to 13.9 nm.
More recently, Wan and co-workers reported an interesting surfactant-free and silica-free system for the synthesis of HPCS by the selective dissolution of 3-aminophenol/formaldehyde resin (3-AF) spheres (Figure 3e).[44,45] They confirmed that the polymerization of 3-aminophenol and formaldehyde in the mixture of water/NH4OH produced solid 3-AF spheres with inhomogeneous chemical compositions: 3-AF oligomer interiors and high-molecular-weight 3-AF exteriors (oligomer@ polymer). Since the oligomer interiors are soluble, hollow 3-AF spheres can be obtained after treating the solid spheres with acetone. When hollow 3-AF spheres were used as the templates, multishelled hollow 3-AF spheres were further obtained after repeating the growth-and-removal procedures for a certain number of cycles. This work provides a controllable route to synthesize multishelled HPCS.
With the rapid development of the synthesis methodology, it has become a practice for researchers to design and synthesize, especially using the hard-templating strategy, HPCM with desired structural parameters toward specific applications. However, the mass production of HPCM is still a big challenge. Most of the reported methods, although facile and effective, are still at the stage of laboratory research. Another challenge for the synthesis of HPCM is how to reduce the producing cost. It is particularly crucial for the hard-templating strategy. Minimizing the tedious procedures for the formation and removal of the templates is of great significance to promoting the practical applications of the hard-templating strategy. Therefore, the simplified Stöber methods are still to be improved.

sections.heading: 3. Sulfur Cathodes Based on Hollow Porous Carbon Materials
sections.text: In the past decade, the design of sulfur composite cathodes based on conductive host materials is the most preferred choice for improving the performance of Li–S batteries. With the progress in their controllable synthesis, HPCM and its derived materials provide tremendous opportunities for sulfur cathodes. For an easier comparison, in the following sections we classified these HPCM-based cathodes into several categories according to the geometric structures and components of HPCM (i.e., spheres, 1D structures, 2D structures, hierarchical structures, and composite structures). In addition, the HPCMderived self-supporting sulfur cathodes are discussed as an independent category.

sections.heading: 3.1. Hollow Porous Carbon Spheres
sections.text:
Since HPCS is easily available from the hard- and soft-templating methods as discussed above, optimizing the structural parameters of HPCS has been intensively investigated. A classic example can be traced back to the work reported by Archer and co-workers in 2011 (Figure 4a).[46] By using the inverse replica of the silica templates, HPCS with an SSA of 648 m2 g1 and a pore size of 3 nm was synthesized and tested as a sulfurhosting material. After exposing the HPCS to sulfur vapor, the HPCS/S composites with 70 wt% of sulfur delivered a high initial capacity of 1100 mAh g−1 and maintained a reversible

Based on the co-assembly of RF, SiO2, and cationic surfactant in a modified Stöber condition, Nazar and co-workers synthesized the HPCS with different pore parameters and systematically investigated how the porosity of HPCS affects the performance of the HPCS/S cathodes (Figure 4b).[47] Although the mesoporous channels of HPCS are beneficial for impregnation of sulfur, enhancing charge transfer, and accommodating volume expansion of sulfur, the porous framework also facilitates the dissolution and diffusion of polysulfides. Therefore, tuning the porosity of HPCS is very important to improve the capacity and stability of the HPCS/S cathodes. Aiming to tune and optimize the porosity, a series of HPCS were further investigated using various hard and soft templates.[48–56]
In addition to single-shelled HPCS, multishelled HPCS has also been designed as sulfur-hosting materials. Lou and coworkers developed a double-shelled HPCS employing prefabricated hollow SnO2 spheres as the hard template (Figure 4c).[57] The two shells were connected by carbon “links” and gave rise to a large SSA and high pore volume. Therefore, the doubleshelled HPCS could effectively reduce the outward diffusion of polysufildes and withstand volume expansion of sulfur. Wang and co-workers synthesized multishelled hollow RF/SiO2/surfactant spheres and multishelled HPCS by an emulsion-based soft-templating method.[58] Based on the disproportionation reaction of Na2S, NaS2O3, and HCl, the newly generated sulfur was deposited into the interlayer voids of multishelled HPCS, resulting in a multishelled HPCS/S composite with a high sulfur content of 86 wt%. The multishelled HPCS/S cathode delivered an enhanced cycling stability (1250 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.1 C) and a good rate capability (452 mAh g−1 at 5 C). Zheng and co-workers designed a multiple coating strategy for the controlled synthesis of HPCS and hollow-inhollow-structured HPCS@HPCS (Figure 4d).[59] Although HPCS@HPCS and HPCS have the similar porosities, the HPCS@HPCS/S cathode delivered a better cycling stability than the HPCS/S cathode. The enhanced performance can be attributed to the unique protection provided by the outer HPCS shell, which can trap the polysulfides derived from the inner HPCS core. Moreover, the hollow-in-hollow structure can

In another case, based on the confined nanospace pyrolysis of core/shell-structured PB@SiO2 spheres, Lu and co-workers obtained the solid-inhollow-structured carbon sphere@HPCS (CS@HPCS) spheres (Figure 4e).[60] With the protection of the outer carbon layer, the CS@HPCS/S composite with 70 wt% of sulfur exhibited the enhanced cycling stability and rate performance. When the sulfur content was further increased to 85 wt%, the CS@ HPCS/S cathode still delivered the discharge capacities of 720 and 590 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.4 and 3.2 C, respectively.
Although physically confining sulfur in the pore channels of HPCM could increase the sulfur utilization, the weak interaction between the nonpolar carbon and polar polysulfides is not enough to effectively immobilize polysulfides on the carbon surface. Doping heteroatom (e.g., N or S) into the skeleton of carbon materials is thus developed as a convenient method to enhance the chemisorption between polysulfides and carbon hosts.[61–63] Xiao and co-workers synthesized the N-doped HPCS (N-HPCS) with different pore sizes of 4.1, 3.2, and 2.8 nm by using porous silica particles as the hard templates and poly dopamine as the carbon precursor.[64] With a high sulfur content of 85 wt%, the N-HPCS/S composites exhibited the improved cycling stabi lities. Observing with scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), they confirmed that sulfur can be impregnated into the inner cavity of N-HPCS, but would overflow the carbon shell during the lithiation process. After being coated with an additional layer of polydopamine, the N-HPCS/S composites delivered a stable capacity of 630 mAh g−1 after 600 cycles at 0.6 C. By employing the RF- and PB-based Stöber system, Zheng and co-workers optimized structural parameters of HPCS with different porosities, N contents, and morphologies toward the performance of the HPCS/S cathodes (Figure 4f).[42] The comparison of the structural parameters revealed that the integration of large SSA, high pore volume, and high N content provided a better binding interface for the immobilization of sulfur and polysulfides. As an optimized architecture, the bowl-like N-HPCS with an SSA of 2161 m2 g−1, a pore volume of 1.5 m3 g−1, and a N content of 5.1 at% exhibited the significantly enhanced rate capabilities (535 mAh g−1 at 4 C) and cycling stabilities (706 mAh g−1 after 400 cycles at 1 C). More importantly, the bowl-like structure can reduce the inner cavity of N-HPCS and improve the trap density of the N-HPCS/S composite greatly, leading to a high volumetric energy density (817 mAh cm−3).

sections.heading: 3.2. 1D Hollow Carbon Structures
sections.text:
With a high aspect ratio, 1D hollow porous carbon fibers (HPCF) can form a conductive network for both electronic and ionic transports, which is beneficial to improving the reaction kinetics of the C/S composite cathodes. As a convenient hard template, anodized aluminum oxide (AAO) membrane is widely used in the synthesis of HPCF and HPCF/S composites. Wang and co-workers fabricated the HPCF/S composites with 40 wt% of sulfur by a two-step treatment of the AAO-derived HPCF (i.e., the low-temperature sulfur impregnation and the hightemperature sulfur intercalation).[65] This approach ensured that most of sulfur was loaded in the carbon shell of HPCF. Cui
and co-workers reported a smart method ensuring the selective deposition of sulfur into the inner space of HPCF by heating a mixture of sulfur and AAO@C (Figure 5a). The AAO@C/S composites were converted into the S@HPCF composites, after the removal of AAO. With 75 wt% of sulfur content, the S@HPCF composites delivered a reversible capacity of 706 mAh g−1 after 150 cycles at 0.2 C.[66] By heating the Pt layer sealed AAO@C/S composites at 400 °C, Kim and co-workers obtained S@HPCF composites filled with sulfur nanowires (Figure 5b).[67] Interestingly, a majority of sulfur nanowires processes the unusual monoclinic phase rather than the orthorhombic phase, and the S@ HPCF nanowires exhibited a high rate capability (≈940 mAh g−1 at 20 C and 453 mAh g−1 at 40 C).
To avoid the formation of the long-chain polysulfides (i.e., S8 → Li2S8–4), Guo and co-workers designed hollow micro porous carbon fibers by coating the multiwalled carbon nanotubes (m-CNTs) with microporous carbon shells (Figure 5c).[68] Since the hollow microporous carbon fibers had a narrow pore size distribution of 0.5 nm, sulfur was loaded in the confined space in the form of the small sulfur allotropes (S2–4) rather than the conventional cyclo-S8 molecules. These C/S2–4 composite fibers not only presented an interesting electrochemical behavior with a single discharge plateau (≈1.9 V), but also exhibited a favorable cycling stability (1149 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.1 C). This strategy can effectively minimize the effect of polysulfides, but the insufficient pore volume limits the total sulfur loading into the hollow carbon fibers (≈40 wt%), which decreases the energy density of the battery. Therefore, the combination of micropores and mesopores is expected to generate better HPCF with balanced sulfur loading and cycling stability.[69–71]
In addition to the traditional HPCF, some novel 1D structures have also been developed as the sulfur-hosting materials. By using the acid-treated m-CNT as the functional core and mesoporous silica as the sacrificial layer (Figure 5d), Guan and co-workers designed a tube-in-tube-structured HPCF (m-CNT@ HPCF).[72] The coupling of the highly conductive m-CNT and the highly porous HPCF allowed the m-CNT@HPCF/S composite with 71 wt% of sulfur to exhibit high capacity (1274 mAh g−1 at 0.3 C) and good rate performance (550 mAh g−1 at 3.6 C). Based on the AAO-templated HPCF, another type of tube-intube-structured m-CNT@HPCF was reported by Wang and co-workers (Figure 5e).[73] When using Cu particle catalyst– decorated AAO membrane as the template, m-CNTs grown inside each HPCF were synthesized via a chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method. Even with a high sulfur content of 85 wt%, the m-CNT@HPCF/S composite exhibited significantly improved sulfur utilization (1633 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C) and rate capability (954 mAh g−1 after 150 cycles at 5 C). Compared with the AAO-templated method, the electrospinning method has even more advantages in the large-scale synthesis of HPCF. Manthiram and co-workers reported the synthesis of multichannel HPCM using a single-nozzle co-electrospinning technique (Figure 5f).[74] The multichannel HPCM was further activated with KOH to create micropores on the channel walls, combining the benefits of both micropores and mesopores. In the activated multichannel HPCF, the mesoporous multichannel enhanced the sulfur loading and sulfur utilization, while the micropores provided trapping sites for the immobilization of polysulfides. sections.heading: 3.3. 2D Hollow Carbon Structures
sections.text:
From the viewpoint of morphology, 2D hollow porous carbon nanosheets (HPCN) can be considered as an upgraded version of HPCS with the following advantages: 1) the porous carbon layer allows HPCN to inherit the structural merits of HPCS, especially the high SSA and large pore volume; 2) high lengthto-thickness ratio helps HPCN to optimize its inner cavity
and reduce the unused voids; 3) the 2D character decreases the charge-transport resistance and diffusion distance within HPCN. Although HPCN is an attractive sulfur-hosting material, the HPCN-based cathodes are still in their infancy due to lacking of efficient synthesis methods for HPCN. Most of HPCN reported so far were mainly fabricated by coating porous metal oxide nanosheets with carbon precursors.[75]
Zhang and co-workers reported the CVD growth of HPCN with Mg–Al layered double hydroxide (Mg–Al LDH) nanosheets as both catalyst and templates (Figure 6a).[76] Since the Mg–Al LDH nanosheets were converted into the porous Mg–Al layered oxide nanosheets during the heating process, the resulted HPCN composed of two separate graphene layers connected by the perpendicular mesochannels. With a sulfur content of 64 wt%, the HPCN/S composite exhibited enhanced rate capability and cycling stability. The reversible capacities of 1200, 857, and 713 mAh g−1 were obtained at 1, 5, and 10 C, respectively. As a result, the pore size and volume of the Zn–Mg–Al LDH-derived HPCN were remarkably higher than those of Mg–Al LDH-derived HPCN, enabling the HPCN/S composite to achieve enhanced cycling stabilities. sections.text:

Compared with the nano- or sub-micrometer scale HPCM, the micro meter scale hierarchically structured HPCM not only inherits the structural characteristics of the primary HPCM units, but also provides additional advantages from the assembly, such as high tap density, fast charge transport, and hierarchically porous network.[78–80] When used as sulfur-hosting materials, the

Cui and co-workers reported the synthesis of the pomegranate-like HPCS clusters using the preassembled SiO2 spheres as the hierarchically structured templates and RF as the carbon precursor (Figure 7a).[78] Compared with HPCS prepared from individual SiO2 spheres (i.e., the primary unit), the HPCS clusters have an improved capability of suppressing the polysulfide shuttling, as the sulfur species in the inner cores of the HPCS clusters are difficult to diffuse out. To further improve the cycling stability of the HPCS/S clusters, they coated the HPCS/S clusters with a layer of conductive polymer, poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT), which serves as a protective layer to limit the polysulfide diffusion. The resulted cathode delivered a stabilized capacity over 700 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at 0.5 C. In addition, the space-efficient packing of HPCS clusters endowed the cathode with high rate capability (733 mAh g−1 at 3 C) and high volumetric energy density (1290 Wh L−1). Based on 3D hyperbranched MgO nanorods obtained by chemical vapor transport and the condensation method (Mg(vapor) + H2O(gas) → MgO(solid) + H2 (gas)), Wang and co-workers reported the MgO-templated CVD growth of the hierarchically structured HPCF (Figure 7b).[79] The hierarchically structured HPCF has a high aspect ratio and multiple

Recently, a similar MgO-templated process was proposed by Zheng and co-workers to fabricate hierarchically structured HPCN (Figure 7c).[80] Based on the hydrolyzation reaction of MgO, they developed a facile method for the controllable synthesis of layered metal hydroxide nanosheets and their derived hierarchical structures.[81,82] Starting with the MgO microrods, the hierarchically structured carbon microrods composed of vertically aligned HPCN were synthesized by the hydrolyzation of MgO and then CVD growth of carbon. With the high SSA (2226 m2 g−1), large pore volume (4.9 cm3 g−1), and interconnected macroporous network, the hierarchically structured HPCN can improves the sulfur utilization at a relatively high sulfur content (>70 wt%). Even at an ultrahigh sulfur content of 88.8 wt%, sulfur was well confined in the framework of the hierarchically structured HPCN, resulting in good rate capability (545 mAh g−1 at 3 C) and cycling stability (632 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 1 C).

sections.heading: 3.5. Hollow Carbon Composite Materials
sections.text:
Compared with nonpolar carbon materials, the sulfur-hosting materials with polar surfaces usually have a higher ability to anchor polysulfides due to the strong interaction between polar host materials and polar polysulfides.[83,84] Many polar inorganic materials, such as metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal hydroxides, metal carbides, and metal organic frameworks, have been investigated as the sulfur-hosting materials.[85–88] In addition to the improved polysulfide-binding abilities, some polar inorganic materials can also accelerate the redox kinetics for the reduction of polysulfides.[89–91] However, most of polar inorganic materials are not conductive; therefore, composite structures combining HPCM and polar inorganic material have been proposed and subsequently proved a promising choice.[92]
Modifying the carbon shell of HPCM with polar inorganic nanoparticles is a straightforward strategy.[26,93–95] Wu and coworkers decorated HPCS by embedding CoO nanoparticles into prefabricated HPCS (HPCS/CoO, Figure 8a).[95] Due to the chemical interaction between CoO and polysulfides, HPCS/ CoO possesses a superior polysulfide adsorption capability in comparison to HPCS only. With a sulfur content of 71.3 wt%, the HPCS/CoO/S composite exhibited the enhanced cycle stability (629 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 1.0 C) and rate capability (620 mAh g−1 at 5.0 C). In contrast, the capacities of the HPCS/S composite under the same test conditions were 302 and 387 mAh g−1, respectively. To simplify the synthesis procedures, Jin and co-workers developed a self-templating method using ZIF-67 as both carbon and polar inorganic nanoparticle precursors (Figure 8b).[26] Simply by annealing the thioacetamide-treated ZIF-67 particles at 350 °C in N2 atmosphere, N-doped hollow porous carbon particles embedded with metallic and polar Co9S8 nanoparticles (N-HPCP/Co9S8) were
synthesized as an efficient sulfur host. Since the embedded Co9S8 nanoparticles efficiently improved the confinement of polysulfides and the redox reaction kinetics, these N-HPCP/ Co9S8/S composites with 77 wt% of sulfur delivered a reversible capacity of 560 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 2 C.
Taking advantage of the hard-templating method widely used for core/shell and yolk/shell structures is another effective strategy for combining HPCM with polar inorganic materials.[96,97] Lou and co-workers reported the synthesis of hollow-structured TiO@C spheres by the reduction of hollowstructured TiO2@C spheres (Figure 8c).[98] With high density of Ti and O vacancies, TiO can provide more effective adsorption of polysulfides than TiO2. By immobilizing sulfur within the porous shells and cavity of the TiO@C spheres, the TiO2@C/S composites with 70 wt% of sulfur delivers capacities of 750 mAh g−1 (0.2 C) and 630 mAh g−1 (0.5 C) after 500 cycles. In their recent work, a grape cluster–structured fiber composed of closely packed hollow-structured TiO@C spheres was further developed utilizing the electrospinning technique.[99] This grape-cluster-like structure allows the TiO@C/S cathode with 5 mg cm−2 of sulfur to provide a stable capacity of 630 mAh g−1 after 400 cycles at 0.2 C. Since the hard-templating method can make use of core/shell-structured materials as the templates, the yolk/shell-structured HPCM with polar inorganic cores have also been investigated as sulfur-hosting materials.[100–103] For instance, Lou and co-workers developed a hybrid structure of hollow carbon fiber filled with MnO2 nanosheets (MnO2@HCF) using MnO2 nanowires as the templates (Figure 8d).[104] Manthiram and co-workers designed yolk/shell-structured Fe3O4@C nanoboxes with Fe2O3 nanocubes as the templates (Figure 8e).[105] With the polar inorganic cores, these yolk/ shell-structured HPCM endow the sulfur cathodes with higher capacities and prolonged cycle lives in comparison to their HPCM counterparts. These works indicate that the coupling of HPCM and polar inorganic materials offers new opportunities for the development of high-performance sulfur hosts.

sections.heading: 3.6. Self-Supporting Sulfur Cathodes
sections.text:
High-sulfur-loading cathodes with high sulfur utilization and good cycling stabilities are the prerequisite for realizing the high-energy-density Li–S batteries. In literature, the slurrycoating procedure is the most commonly used procedure for fabricating sulfur cathodes. Unfortunately, although the sulfur content of many host/sulfur composites can reach up to 70 wt%, the use of polymer binder (usually 10 wt% of slurry) and commercial carbon black (usually 10–20 wt% of slurry) in the slurrycoating procedure results in that the sulfur content in the whole cathode is lower than 60 wt%.[3] Moreover, many sulfur cathodes are constructed with an areal sulfur loading of 1–2 mg cm−2, leading to low areal capacities.[3] However, the performance of cathodes decreases rapidly when simply increasing the sulfur content or the electrode thickness, due to the weakened host– sulfur(polysulfides) interaction, the impeded ion/electron transport, and the increased resistance.[106] In order to develop high-sulfur-loading cathodes, recent efforts are focusing on the self-supporting cathodes. A common characteristic of the reported self-supporting cathodes is to use the freestanding

Considering that the HPCM particles (e.g., HPCS) can hardly build up freestanding films by themselves, assistant materials are employed to help the HPCM particles to construct self-supporting cathodes (Figure 9a). Manthiram and co-workers assembled the N-HPCS/S composite and graphene to form a self-supporting cathode (N-HPCS/S-G).[108] For the N-HPCS/S-G structure, the lightweight graphene network wrapped on the surface of N-HPCS not only facilitates electron transfer, but also provides an additional physical barrier for polysulfides. With the dual confinement of sulfur provided by N-HPCS and graphene, the N-HPCS/S-G cathode
with 62 wt% and 3.9 mg cm−2 of sulfur exhibited a high sulfur utilization (1360 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C) and sustainable cycling stability (520 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.5 C). To utilize the polysulfide adsorption property of polar inorganic materials, they further developed a self-supporting cathode by the vacuum filtration of the ZIF-67-derived N-HPCP/Co3S4, activated carbon nanofiber, and sulfur powder.[109] Benefiting from and the conductive carbon nanofiber network and the strong interaction between Co3S4 and polysulfides, the selfsupporting cathode with 52–55 wt% and 13.5 mg cm−2 of sulfur delivered an initial capacity of 957 mAh g−1 (13 mAh cm−2) at 0.3 C and maintained a capacity of 550 mAh g−1 (7.5 mAh cm−2) after 100 cycles.
Compared to HPCM particles, 1D HPCF has an overwhelming advantage in the formation of freestanding films. By using glass microfiber filter paper as the template and

Li and co-workers reported the fabrication of high-sulfur-loading cathodes by using natural cotton (Figure 9c).[111] The carbonization of natural cotton produced freestanding HPCF foams, which can accommodate large amounts of sulfur and improve the overall areal sulfur loading. A mixture containing 90 wt% sulfur, 5 wt% CNT, and 5 wt% carbon black was impregnated into the macroporous structure of the HPCF foam, resulting in a selfsupporting cathode with 76 wt% and 21.2 mg cm−2 of sulfur. After being decorated with an interlayer film (see detailed functions of interlayers in the following section), this selfsupporting cathode delivered a reasonably high areal capacity of 14.8 mAh cm−2 after 150 cycles at 3.55 mA cm−2. It is noteworthy that most of the self-supporting cathodes made by HPCS or HPCF often have high areal capacities but low volumetric capacities, due to the excess void space inside the freestanding host/sulfur composite films. To address this issue, Zheng and co-workers designed closely packed self-supporting cathodes with 2D HPCN (Figure 9d).[113] Starting with graphene oxide sheets, a 2D yolk–shell structure with graphene encapsulated in N-doped HPCN (G@N-HPCN) was synthesized by a PB-based Stöber system. The high SSA (2296 m2 g−1), lager pore volume (2.1 m3 g−1), and high N content (4.5 at%) made G@N-HPCN a favorable sulfur-hosting material to improve sulfur utilization and suppress shuttling of polysulfides. By co-assembling G@N-HPCN/S composite and graphene, the self-supporting cathodes (G@N-HPCN/S-G) with 73 wt% and 5–10 mg cm−2 of sulfur were further fabricated with a brickwall-like structure. The coupling of the high-performance sulfur host (i.e., G@N-HPCN) and conductive graphene resulted in high-sulfur-loading cathodes with enhanced rate capability and cycling stability. In addition, the closely packed structure minimized the excess void space inside the cathodes, leading to the improved volumetric capacities. With 10 mg cm−2 of sulfur, the G@N-HPCN/S-G cathode delivered a high capacity of 11.4 mAh cm−2 (1330 mAh cm−3) after 50 cycles at 0.1 C. It is demonstrated that 2D HPCN was capable of balancing the areal and volumetric capacities of the self-supporting cathodes. Despite the progress in the increment of sulfur content and areal sulfur loading, most of the self-supporting cathodes are still facing two main challenges: 1) both rate performance and cycle life need to be further improved; 2) the manufacturing protocol is not compatible with current commercial battery production.

sections.heading: 4. Modified Separators with Hollow Carbon Materials
sections.text:
Separator is an important battery component to separate the cathode and anode in Li–S batteries. The porosity and thickness of separator can affect the ion transport pathway and the internal resistance of batteries.[106,114] As mentioned above, the migration of the polysulfide intermediates from cathode to anode is one major cause of the rapid capacity fading of Li–S batteries. Besides designing better sulfur-hosting materials, creating a barrier layer to block the polysulfide migration is another way to improve the cycling stability of Li–S batteries. In 2012, Su and Manthiram reported that inserting a freestanding microporous carbon interlayer between the cathode and the separator could effectively suppress the shuttling.[12] They demonstrated that the microporous carbon interlayer not only helped to capture/localize the dissolved polysulfides within the cathode side, but also served as an upper current collector to reduce the charge-transfer resistance and increase the active material utilization. When combined with the microporous carbon interlayer, the carbon/sulfur cathode made by commercial carbon black delivered a high capacity of over 1000 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 1 C. Therefore, the concept of interlayer is also beneficial to reducing cost of cathode. Since then, various interlayers have been developed as polysulfide barriers. However, it should be pointed out that many interlayers are higher than 0.3 mg cm−2, decreasing the energy density of the batteries.[115]
To address this problem, an alternative strategy is to coat the barrier layer on one surface of commercial separators.[116] By using the separator as the substrate, the weight and thickness of barrier layer can be easily controlled. Moreover, a modified separator is much easier to handle during battery assembly than an independent interlayer. Compared with particles and 1D nanostructures, 2D nanostructures have a unique advantage in the formation of a dense and continuous thin film. Therefore, some 2D nanomaterials, such as graphene and surfacefunctionalized graphene, black-phosphorus, and MoS2, have been used to modify separators as the barrier layers.[117–119] Recently, Zheng and co-workers demonstrated that the yolk/ shell-structured G@N-HPCN was an attractive candidate for lightweight and high-performance barrier layers (Figure 10).[19] When using the commercial Celgard separator as a filter, G@N-HPCN were easily deposited onto the surface of the separator with the simple vacuum filtration method, resulting in a brickwall-structured G@N-HPCN layer-modified separator (G@N-HPCN/Celgard). With a low thickness of 0.9 mm, the G@N-HPCN layer was only 0.075 mg cm2. The polysulfidetrapping capability of G@N-HPCN/Celgard was confirmed superior to those of separators modified with other carbon materials (e.g., carbon black, CNT, and graphene). With the help of G@N-HPCN/Celgard, the high-sulfur-loading cathodes made of commercially available carbon materials delivered improved performances. For instance, the CNT/S cathode with 70 wt% and 6 mg cm2 of sulfur displayed a high capacity of 793 mAh g−1 with a capacity retention of 81.2% after 400 cycles at 0.5 C, and the CNT/S cathode with 70 wt% and 12 mg cm2 of sulfur exhibited a high area capacity of 12.1 mAh cm−2 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C. sections.heading: 5. Lithium Anodes Based on Hollow Porous Carbon Materials
sections.text:
With the rapid development of sulfur cathodes, the safety concerns and short lifespan of Li metal anodes need to be revisited for the practical application of Li–S batteries, as the commercialization of Li metal batteries was halted after
numerous attempts to address the safety issue were failed in the 1980s.[121] Fortunately, Li-metal anodes are experiencing a renaissance in the past few years. Some effective approaches, such as modifying electrolytes, fabricating artificial solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layers, introducing protection layers, and incorporating Li hosts or current collectors, have been developed to obtain Li-metal anodes with significant enhanced performances.[121]
The challenges of Li metal anodes are mainly derived from the high reactivity of lithium and the formation of Li dendrites. The continuous reaction between electrolyte and Li metal anode generates SEI layer, leading to the consumption of the

Moreover, the Li dendrites’ growth not only can puncture the separator and induce an internal short circuit, but also triggers the continuous formation of SEI layer and “dead Li,” resulting in low Coulombic efficiency and poor cycling stability.[121] To reduce the safety risks and improve the cycling efficiency, many research activities have been developed to prevent the Li dendrites’ growth. It is well known that the Li deposition behavior can be regulated by the current collector. However, the high Li nucleation overpotential and low surface area make it difficult for commercial Cu current collectors to realize a dendrite-free Li deposition. In the past few years, using the carbon materials to modify or replace Cu current collectors has emerged as an effective route to suppress the Li dendrites’ growth.[122]
The permeable shell and confined cavity are two typical characteristics of HPCM that can be utilized to construct stabi lized Li-metal anodes. Cui and co-workers developed a polystyrene sphere-templated flash evaporation route to construct a monolayer of interconnected amorphous HPCS on the surface of Cu current collector (Figure 11a).[123] This electrochemically stable HPCS layer had a high Young’s modulus (≈200 GPa) and served as an artificial SEI layer to suppress Li dendrites without impacting the Li-ion diffusion. Due to the weak interaction between HPCS and Cu, the HPCS layer can move up/down along with the Li plating/stripping, providing a stretchable buffering space for Li deposition. Moreover, the HPCS layer could regulate the Li deposition behavior, and column-like Li was deposited on the Cu current collector. When cycled at a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2 and deposition areal capacity of 1.0 mAh cm−2, the HPCS layer–protected Li metal anode delivered a high Coulombic efficiency of 99% for over 150 cycles. To make better use of the confined space, they reported the selective deposition of Li metal within the inner cavity of HPCS by designing the yolk–shell-structured HPCS (Figure 11b).[124] They investigated the overpotentials of Li nucleation on different substrates and found that metals with a definite Li solubility (e.g., Au, Ag, and Zn) had lower nucleation overpotentials in comparison to metals with no Li solubility (e.g., Cu, Ni, C, Sn, and Si). When the yolk–shell-structured Au@HPCS was employed, the nucleation and growth of Li metal were successfully confined inside HPCS, as the deposition of Li metal was preferably on the Au cores, rather than on the hollow carbon shells. In the confined space provided by HPCS, the Au-seeds induced Li deposition resulted in a dendrite-free Li metal anode with significantly enhanced cycling stability (Coulombic efficiency of ≈98% after 300 cycles at 1.0 mA cm−2/0.5 mAh cm−2 in alkyl carbonate electrolyte). Recently, Cui and co-workers further optimized the selective deposition strategy by coating a dense Al2O3 layer onto the HPCS layer via atomic layer deposition (Figure 11c).[125] The Al2O3 coating layer served two important functions: 1) the electrical conductivity differences between Al2O3 and HPCS induced the selective deposition of Li metal onto the inner surface of HPCS only, and 2) the dense Al2O3 layer prevented the penetration of electrolyte into the inner cavity of HPCS@Al2O3, thus minimizing the side reactions between Li metal and electrolyte, the consumptions of Li metal, and the dosage of electrolyte. As a result, the Li@HPCS@Al2O3 anode delivered a high Coulombic efficiency of 99% after 500 cycles at 1.0 mA cm−2/0.5 mAh cm−2 in an ether-based electrolyte.
During the Li deposition process, the current density has a major influence on morphologies of Li. In general, the Li dendrites’ growth can be restrained by reducing the local current density. HPCM-based current collectors can be designed to provide more Li nucleation sites and to reduce the local current density at the same time. Zhang and co-workers developed a carbon-modified current collector by coating the Mg–Al LDH-templated HPCN onto Cu foil.[126] Benefiting from the high SSA (1666 m2 g−1) of HPCN, the modified Cu foil significantly reduced the local current density, leading to a dendrite-free Li deposition behavior. In addition, the large pore volume (1.65 cm3 g−1) of HPCN endowed the HPCN-modified Cu foil with a high Li capacity of 5.0 mAh cm−2. The resultant Li metal anode delivered a Coulombic efficiency of 93% at 2 mA cm−2/5 mAh cm−2 in a dual-salt electrolyte. Compared to HPCS and HPCN, 1D structured HPCF is a favorable choice to form a freestanding conductive network, which can be directly used as a current collector for Li metal anode. Guo and co-workers developed a low-cost and high-performance HPCF current collector via the carbonization of commercial cotton (Figure 11d).[127] The cotton-derived HPCF network had good mechanical properties and high electroactive surface area, thus provided a robust current collector to reduce the local current density. As Li can be deposited both within the interfiber space and the inner cavities of individual HPCF fibers, the HPCF current collector is an attractive “Li host” to accommodate a large quantity of deposited Li (e.g., deposition areal capacity of 6 mAh cm−2) without the presence of Li dendrites. The Coulombic efficiency of the HPCF/Li anode maintained at ≈99% for 90 cycles at 2 mA cm−2/4 mAh cm−2 and ≈99% for 75 cycles at 1 mA cm−2/6 mAh cm−2.
In addition, HPCM is both a sulfur-hosting material and a Li-hosting material; therefore, the use of HPCM as two-in-one hosts has been recently investigated for constructing Li–S batteries. Ji and co-workers synthesized a covalently connected carbon nanostructure by the CVD growth of CNT bundles on the surface of macroporous graphite foams (MGF).[128] After the sulfur impregnation, the CNT-MGF/S composite with 43 wt% and 2.4 mg cm−2 of sulfur was used as a self-supporting cathode and delivered a capacity of 818 mAh g−1 after 400 cycles at 0.5 C. When the CNT–MGF was electroplated with Li metal, the CNT–MGF/Li anode showed a low-voltage hysteresis of 10 mV after 800 h of cycling at 0.25 mA cm−2. By pairing a CNT–MGF/S cathode (47 wt% and 2.6 mg cm−2 of sulfur) with a CNT–MGF/Li anode (20 wt% of Li), the Li–S battery exhibited a stable capacity over 770 mAh g−1 (calculation based on the mass of sulfur) after 400 cycles at 2 C. In another work reported by Yu and co-workers, a trench-wall CNT sponge was synthesized by etching a 3D sponge-like CNT framework in a KMnO4/H2SO4 mixture.[129] With the increased surface area and surface functional groups, the trench-wall CNT sponge had both high polysulfide-bonding capability and high lithiophilicity (Figure 11e). Moreover, the 3D porous framework makes the trench-wall CNT sponge accommodate high amounts of sulfur or lithium. As a result, a high areal capacity of Li–S battery was successfully obtained by using trench-wall CNT sponge as two-in-one hosts, and a high areal capacity of over 7 mAh cm−2 was maintained after 250 cycles at 4.8 mA cm−2. sections.heading: 6. Summary and Perspectives
sections.text:
In summary, recent advances in the hard-templating synthesis of HPCM and the rational design of HPCM or its derivatives toward sulfur cathodes, separators, and Li metal anodes are reviewed and discussed. With highly designable morphology and structural parameters, HPCM show great potentials in Li–S battery research and development. As a highly controllable and reproducible method, the hard-templating strategy has apparent advantages in fabricating HPCM with desired morphologies, sizes, compositions, and pore structures. It provides researchers an efficient tool to design the HPCM according to desired functions. The success of the modified Stöber method not only revives the moderate and scalable sol–gel process used in the HPCM precursor synthesis, but also simplifies some complicated procedures (e.g., precursor coating and pore structure control) used in the conventional hard-templating method. Many research fields involving Li–S batteries will continue to benefit from the improvement of the modified Stöber method.
The employment of HPCM as conductive host materials for sulfur cathodes has achieved significant progresses. From physical interaction (e.g., physical adsorption and spatial confinement) to interfacial chemical interaction (e.g., chemisorption and catalytic conversion of polysulfides), increasing the sulfur utilization while decreasing the dissolution of polysulfides into the electrolyte is the basis of constructing the high-performance HPCM/S cathodes. The rational design of their porosities, morphologies, and compositions allows HPCM to significantly improve the capacities, rate capabilities, and cycling stabilities of sulfur cathodes. The performance of HPCM can be further improved by coupling with polar inorganic materials. Assembling HPCM to create self-supporting structures provides a convenient method for the fabrication of high-sulfur-loading cathodes with enhanced energy densities. Some specific structures such as multilayered-, concave-, and 2D HPCM structures can greatly improve the volumetric energy density of the HPCM/S cathodes by reducing the excess void space inside these structures. In addition, 2D HPCM has a unique advantage in the preparation of the lightweight polysulfide barrier–modified separators, which can help the highsulfur-loading cathodes made by commercial carbon materials to deliver significantly improved capacities and cycling stabilities. More importantly, the recent revival of research on Li-dendrite formation and growth reveals a bright prospect of HPCM in the development of stable and safe Li metal anodes. Manipulating the permeable shell and confined cavity of HPCM for the selective deposition of Li metal within the protected space can suppress dendritic Li formation and reduce the side reactions between Li and electrolyte, resulting in the Li metal anodes with remarkably enhanced Coulombic efficiency and cycling stability. Replacing commercial Cu current collectors with 3D porous HPCM current collectors can induce a dendrite-free Li deposition with low local current densities. This provides a feasible route to improve the cycling efficiency and areal capacity
of Li metal anodes. As an available option for Li–S full cell, HPCM can serve as two-in-one hosts for stabilizing both sulfur cathode and Li metal anode.
Although much advancement has been achieved for laboratory research, the practical application of Li–S batteries still has a long way to go.[130] Some emerging challenges behind the booming of Li–S battery research should be paid more attention. In the past decade, the advancement in understanding the complex Li–S chemistry not only improves the performance of Li–S batteries, but also makes Li–S batteries a favorable system (or “material application platform,” in other words) that is highly compatible with a variety of materials. We have witnessed the rapid development of sulfur cathodes enabled by the sulfur-hosting materials. However, it is noteworthy that more than 60% of the research articles have focused on designing and synthesizing the sulfur-hosting materials to increase the sulfur utilization and reduce the polysufilde shuttling, while investigations in other critical issues, such as the Li-metal anode protection, the electrolyte formulations, and engineering requirements for full cell productions, are insufficient.[131,132] Although a small portion of cathodes are even able to retain high capacity and stability for over 1000 reversible cycles in the coin cells, the parameters of cathodes and the performance evaluations are very diverse. For instance, the gravimetric capacities of cathodes are usually calculated based on the mass of sulfur. In order to present capacities and cycling stabilities, most of cathodes are evaluated at low-sulfur-loading conditions. Therefore, the gravimetric energy densities and volumetric energy densities of cathodes are still far behind the expectations. More importantly, the electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio used in the coin cells is usually higher than 10 µL mg−1, which dramatically reduces both gravimetric and volumetric energy densities of the batteries. Fortunately, researchers have realized and been striving to narrow the gap between fundamental research and practical applications.[131,132] Technical analyses and comprehensive reviews on the practically necessary parameters for Li–S batteries receive increasingly attention and are also expected to guide the future research trends of Li–S batteries.[130–136] These analyses indicate that the practical Li–S batteries need to be assembled with high-sulfur-loading cathodes (sulfur loading > 6 mg cm−2; sulfur content > 70 wt%; and sulfur utilization > 80%) and a low E/S ratio (<3 µL) to compete with current Li-ion batteries. However, most Li–S batteries presented so far dissatisfy these requirements. Therefore, the next stage of Li–S battery research should focus on developing highenergy Li–S batteries with enhanced cycling stabilities, which raises higher requirements for the sulfur-hosting materials and the cathode structures. It is should be pointed out that the present studies, usually, use Li foil as the anodes, since they are concentrated on improving the sulfur utilization and cycling stability of the cathodes. Additionally, excessive Li can reduce the negative influence of Li dendrites and support the longterm cycling test, especially in the case of low-sulfur-loading batteries. However, when developing high-sulfur-loading batteries, the issues of Li dendrites and Li corrosion must be taken into consideration for both fundamental studies and the practical application, as these issues become more severe with increased sulfur content.[137] Although some strategies have been developed to suppress the Li dendrites’ formation, most of

In facing these emerging challenges, the future development of HPCM may focus on the following aspects. First, scalable and cost-effective synthesis remains vital when designing the HPCM with controllable structural parameters. There is still room for the improvement of the hard-templating method by simplifying the synthesis procedures and using low-cost carbon precursors. The one-pot and one-step synthesis of HPCM in modified Stöber system is worth of being further investigated. Second, the construction of high-performance cathodes is a key research area for the application of HPCM as sulfur-hosting materials, particularly when the slurry-coating fabrication method is employed. Several practically necessary parameters, including high sulfur contents, high areal sulfur loading, and low E/S ratio, must be paid enough attention. Optimizing some important features of HPCM, such as their electrical conductivities, morphologies, and pore structures, can be the starting point for increasing the sulfur contents and the interaction between sulfur/polysulfides and HPCM. The coupling of HPCM and polar materials should be very helpful to further reduce the polysulfide shuttle. More efforts need to be devoted to the proper use of the void space inside HPCM and the rational design of electrode structures, which may help to increase the sulfur loading and reduce the E/S ratio. The closely packed 2D HPCN/S composites with optimized conductive network and mass-transport pathways could be a promising model for constructing high-sulfur-loading cathodes. Third, separators modified with 2D HPCM would play a powerful role for high-sulfur-loading cathodes. A facile and scalable route to fabricate a large-area-modified separator needs to be developed. Roll-to-roll printing and coating techniques will be an interesting choice. Fourth, how to improve the areal capacity and cycling stability of Li/HCPM composite anodes is an important motivation for designing future HCPM. More attention could be paid to the HCPM-based 3D current collectors, since they can accommodate high amounts of lithium and guide dendritefree Li deposition, as well as endure the volume change upon Li plating/stripping. Some problems, such as Li intercalation behavior and high Li consumption in the SEI formation, are expected to be solved or softened by tailoring and optimizing the structural parameters of HCPM. It is desirable to assess the performance and safety of the Li/HCPM composite anodes by pairing them with the high-sulfur-loading cathodes. Last but not the least, researchers should also pay attention to the electrolyte. The electrolyte largely determines electrochemical characteristics of Li–S batteries. As a significant breakthrough in the Li–S battery research, the use of LiNO3 additive in the etherbased electrolyte significantly increased the cycling stabilities and Coulombic efficiencies of Li–S batteries.[138] Optimizing the solvent, lithium salt, and additive of the electrolyte is still a convenient and practical way to improve the performance of the HCPM-based Li–S batteries.[139–143] Although the commercialization of Li–S batteries faces many formidable obstacles, the recent progress illuminates that HPCM can be one of the most anticipated materials to forward the development of Li–S batteries.
